image.altText: A group of men sit solemnly on chairs lined up at the service, some in uniform and wearing medals

items.synopsis: Crowds gather to mark 50 years since troops were withdrawn from the Vietnam War, the longest 20th-century conflict in which Australians participated.

title.children: Australian troops left Vietnam 50 years ago, but for many the pain would continue once they arrived home

image.altText: Several boats are moored at a marina, with palm trees in the background and a shed on the shore

items.synopsis: When two boats set off towards an Indonesian island for a birthday surfing trip, none of those on board could have predicted the next few days. Here's how the survivors managed more than 36 hours at sea.

title.children: How a split-second decision off the island of Aceh may have saved four Australians

image.altText: Alisha Fagan appears serious as she stands outside a court building in Melbourne.

items.synopsis: Alisha Fagan, who caused the death of 69-year-old grandfather Sedat Hassan in a 2022 crash, will be eligible for parole in less than six months.

title.children: Melbourne driver who killed grandfather then blamed crash on 'African men' jailed

image.altText: The ACT Supreme Court towards dusk.

items.synopsis: A jury found Canberra man Shay Kahu Murphy, 32, guilty of 17 charges, including three of sexual intercourse without consent and nine assault offences in relation to four former partners.

title.children: Canberra man sentenced to 14 years in jail for raping and assaulting multiple ex-partners

image.altText: Rear shot of a woman in a purple coat holding a grey mug

items.synopsis: More than 170,000 people across Australia are on the housing waitlist, including people like Annabelle, who faces living out of a car with her cat in a few weeks.

title.children: Annabelle is uni-educated and has an impressive corporate background. She's also homeless at the age of 54

image.altText: A woman looks into the camera and smiles slightly.

items.synopsis: It's legal for one law firm to represent both sides of a real estate transaction but legal experts warn it can make navigating conflict difficult.

title.children: When Christine sold her home, the buyer used the same law firm. Things soon became 'very sticky'

image.altText: A representation of virtual currency Bitcoin and US banknotes.

items.synopsis: Bitcoin's value dropped by as much as 9 per cent after a report about SpaceX's finances, while China's second-largest property developer has filed for Chapter 15 bankruptcy protection. Follow live.

title.children: Bitcoin plummets after SpaceX report, China's Evergrande files for bankruptcy protection in US, ASX picks up

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The local sharemarket managed to claw its way back from the brink to finish flat at the end of trade, up just 2.1 points to 7,148. It's the worst week the ASX has had since last September, and was dragged lower over uncertainties in China and rising bond yields in the US. For the sectors, real estate led the charge throughout the afternoon, up 1.7%, while utilities gained 1.2% and basic materials picked up 0.9%. Consumer cyclicals was the worst performing sector, down 1.2%, while technology shed 0.9% and financials dipped by 0.4%. As for the best performers, it was far and away Magellan's day thanks to its announcement of a special dividend of 30 cents a share, despite a worse than expected 52% drop in its full year profit. The top five performers for today were: Magellan Financial +13.6% Abacus Group +9.4% Goodman Group +7.1% Inghams +6% Amcor +5.6% At the other end, the five worst performers were: Imugene -16% Super Retail Group -6.9% Centuria Capital -5.9% Growthpoint Properties Australia -5.5% Sayona Mining -4.2% And that's where we'll leave the markets blog for the day — and the week. Thanks for your company throughout the day, or if you've been following along throughout the business week. We'll be back to do it all again on Monday, but until then you can catch up on today's developments below, or download the ABC News app and subscribe to our range of news alerts for the latest news.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX finishes flat after suffering worst week in 12 months

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Ever heard that phrase "when the US coughs, the world catches a cold"? That's the theme of a note by Ipek Ozkardeskaya, senior analyst at Swissquote, this afternoon. She unpacked the intensifying "global selloff" we've been seeing thanks to the Fed's latest minutes, where it mentioned that it still sees significant risks to inflation. But she's pointed out that the US Treasury has been printing a lot of T bills lately and fell behind government bond issuance, and will eventually result in Treasury shifting back to bonds — which poses a threat to sovereign yields. "The increasing supply, and the decreasing demand for US sovereigns will be one major force pushing the US yield curve higher. And if the strong economic data translates into higher inflation, the impact on yields will likely be higher," she wrote. The impact of a higher US yield? A stronger US dollar. " A stronger US dollar is inflationary for the rest of the world ," she wrote. "If nothing, the energy and raw material prices that are negotiated in USD terms on international markets simply become more expensive when imports are reverted back to local currencies, and that, alone, is enough to push inflation higher in the rest of the world when the US dollar appreciates. "The EURUSD fell to 1.0856, the AUDUSD slipped below 64 cents and the USDJPY spiked above 146.50. "The correction is in play ... and we could see the US dollar retreat further into the weekly closing bell, but the stronger dollar trend is clearly in play and it is worrying. "
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: The US dollar is getting stronger, and that's 'inflationary for the rest of the world'

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: It might be a bit doom and gloom for oil, but iron ore is one commodity that's set for another solid week. Iron ore futures are trading up on China's Dalian Commodity Exchange, and it's the seventh session in a row they've been edging higher. The reason? It's got to do with the fact China's steelmakers haven't cut production yet, despite the concerns that remain around long-term demand. "Iron ore prices were up strongly on the back of news that steel mills in Hebei have not yet implemented production cuts,"  NAB said in a note. The bank also said it was staying cautious on the 2023 outlook, as China steel production is expected to be capped at 2022 levels. Meanwhile, ANZ mentioned ina note that falling exports from Australia and Brazil have also squeezed iron ore inventories in China.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Iron ore looks set to gain for a second week in a row

image.altText: A man wearing glasses and a suit stands behind a lectern labelled "Working for Australia".

title.children: Albanese defends against attempt to strike nuclear submarines out of Labor platform

image.altText: Naotunne Vijitha Nayaka Thero sits on a couch wearing a crimson robe.

items.synopsis: The Venerable Naotunne Vijitha Nayaka Thero, who is the abbot of the Dhamma Sarana temple in Melbourne's south-east, is facing 13 charges including sexual penetration of a child under 16 and indecent act with a child under 16.

image.altText: red and yellow hazard tape in front of driveway

image.altText: Woman shown MS-2step

items.synopsis: An estimated one in 10 GPs currently provide abortion services. Experts warn that unless the federal government steps in to extend telehealth services, more women will miss out on crucial health care.

image.altText: A close-up shot of large plastic-wrapped packages containing cocaine and taped up with Australian Federal Police tape.

title.children: Police seize half a tonne of cocaine from house after trio allegedly smuggled drugs in via boat

image.altText: Daniel Troy Ames has been jailed for apparent execution style murder of his uncle

items.synopsis: Convicted killer Daniel Troy Ames, who was jailed for the 2009 execution-style murder of his uncle, loses a legal bid to secure a retrial, with an Adelaide court dismissing claims of a deathbed confession by a drug dealer as neither "reliable" nor "compelling".

title.children: Uncle killer loses appeal after court rejects claims of drug dealer 'deathbed confession'

image.altText: Profile photos of two young men.

image.altText: A Holden ute lifted into the air by a crane
